column1: was described at common law as proceedings “unfair to the point that they are contrary to
the interest of justice” (R. v. Power, 1994 CanLII 126 (SCC), [1994] 1 S.C.R. 601, at p. 616),
and as “oppressive treatment” : R. v. Conway, 1989 CanLII 66 (SCC), [1989] 1 S.C.R. 1659,
at p. 1667.....It is a flexible doctrine unencumbered by the specific requirements of concepts
such  as  issue  estoppel. See House of Spring Gardens Ltd. v. Waite, [1990]  3  W.L.R.  347 at  p.
358, [1990]  2  All  E.R.  990  (C.A.).  One  circumstance  in  which  abuse  of  process  has  been
applied is where the litigation before the court is found to be in essence an attempt to relitigate
a claim which the court has already determined."
